To Shippers

The Lake Steamer leaves Selkirk to connect with the Saskatchewan River Steamer at Grand Rapids on the 2nd May 1886.

All Goods at Selkirk at this date will be shipped on the steamer, and will be delivered at destination promptly.

The Winnipeg and Western Transportation Co. Limited, under the direction of Mr. A. W. R. Markley, has prepared to make Special Rates for large shipments, and arrange for payments to meet all charges.

ROYAL MAIL STAGE

WEEKLY.

THE PAC. BAND TRIP

The P. A. C. Band left for Battleford on Monday last, fifth inst., by steamer and arrived here last evening.

There were 14 members of the band, and they were joined by Mr. W. Caddy and his family, who had been engaged in the construction of the new school building at Battleford.

The band was well received by the citizens of Medicine Hat, and was entertained at a dinner given in their honor.

The band then proceeded to Fort Pitt, where they were met by a large crowd of people, who had come out to see them off.

The band then proceeded to Fort Pitt, where they were met by a large crowd of people, who had come out to see them off.

Awarded to Miss Marion Wilson. Prize for General Satisfaction and Application: 1st Prize for English Studies, in the 3rd Class; 2nd Prize for French Studies, in the 3rd Class; 3rd Prize for Music, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Alice Howie, Prize for General Satisfaction: 1st Prize for English Studies, in the 3rd Class; 2nd Prize for French and Latin, in the 3rd Class; 3rd Prize for Music, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Elizabeth Sprague, Prize for General Satisfaction and Application: 1st Prize for English Studies, in the 3rd Class; 2nd Prize for French Studies, in the 3rd Class; 3rd Prize for Music, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Mary McDonald, Prize for General Satisfaction: 1st Prize for English Studies, in the 3rd Class; 2nd Prize for French Studies, in the 3rd Class; 3rd Prize for Music, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Annie Markley, 1st Prize for English Studies, in the 3rd Class; 2nd Prize for French Studies, in the 3rd Class; 3rd Prize for Music, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Nellie Drewry, Prize for General Satisfaction and Application: 1st Prize for Drawing, in the 3rd Class; 2nd Prize for Music, in the 3rd Class; 3rd Prize for French Studies, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Louise Prichard, Prize for General Satisfaction and Application: 1st Prize for English Studies, in the 3rd Class; 2nd Prize for French Studies, in the 3rd Class; 3rd Prize for Music, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Ellie Goodhew, Prize for General Satisfaction and Application: 1st Prize for Writing, in the 3rd Class; 2nd Prize for Needlework, in the 3rd Class; 3rd Prize for French Studies, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Martha M. Ray, Prize for General Satisfaction: 1st Prize for English Studies, in the 3rd Class; 2nd Prize for French Studies, in the 3rd Class; 3rd Prize for Music, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Katie Molloy, 1st Prize for English Studies, in the 3rd Class; 2nd Prize for French Studies, in the 3rd Class; 3rd Prize for Music, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Ada Duggan, 1st Prize for Music, in the 3rd Class.

Miss Marion Wilson, having obtained the highest number of marks during the year, was given the 1st Silver Medal.

The prizes were awarded by Miss Alice Howie, whose marks are only 2 per cent below those of the winner of the 1st Medal.

TELEGRAHIC.

[By Special Telegraph.]

OTTAWA, July 9.—James Fairley has received the following information by telegraph:

The temperance abstention union has invited Alderman Jones to conduct north West Ward.

The military association of Mimico police will have an excursion to Wiarton.

New York boat Tercentenary Larnach.

Chief of the Rigby of Nova Scotia a friend.

Out of sixty-two London seats only eleven have been served by re-electionists.

The polls at midnight were closed.

Mr. James McCauley, chairman of the working men's independent of the Liberal and Unionists, made a speech at the meeting.

It is believed impossible that they will agree to doing so. Gladstone has replied that he cannot agree to any conditions when Lord Salisbury takes office, and they are certain that the Conservative party will not agree to any conditions unless the Liberals agree to do likewise.

It is reported in Government circles that Gladstone is ill-pleased, and he is expected to wage another battle in Parliament. The leaders of every party anticipate a serious contest.

A large return for yesterday was returned by the district of St. John's, containing 49 new cases, 10 deaths; Sault Ste. Marie, 21 new cases, 21 deaths; Sudbury, 24 cases, 4 deaths; Temagami, 16 cases; Cochrane, 17 cases; Cheltenham, 11 cases; Newmarket, 12 cases; and several new cases in the province.

The North West Central contest has not yet been awarded.

Sir John A. Macdonald has been troubled by dissensions in his party.

The Government welcomed the ex-panthers of Scotland for supporting the Gladstonian measure. In his speech announcing the Conservative policy Sir Michael Hicks Beach said that the hon. member for Dundas had been the Irish National League, and opposed Irish obstructionists. Members elected at meetings of the Conservative clubs in Canada.

Several and Secret Acts outrage of a gross character are reported from Ontario.

Cowan & Co. have been given the North West Central Charter.

It is stated an excellent authority that the hon. member has been assured of five years' peace in the territories. It is also stated that Hayter Reid, has been promised by the Premier Commissioner Mr. Miller of the Judicial Office will succeed him in his present position.

A Battery will have its Appeals to morrow for Kingston.

C. H. Graham an American super-annuated army officer who has been employed for the purpose, and now talks of going over the House-Snow Falls.

Wednesday, July 12. The second train from Toronto, already occupied destruction by firemen, through back fires, reached the city yesterday. The passengers were obliged to get off the train and the train thrown off the track because it could not be got under the way. Two cars were destroyed, and the rest were destroyed, considerable damage being also done.

Fred Brown fell from the estate of a house during the general panic, and received probably fatal injuries.

Sir John Macdonald left Ottawa for Winnipeg on Saturday night, and expects to arrive there Monday morning.

Arrangements are being made for his reception.

Chambers & Co. have awarded the North West Central contract.

Sir A. T. Galt and two others have been appointed a commission to inquire into the question of the feasibility of applying a national coin.

A demonstration has been staged granting a general amnesty to all prisoners confined in, or committed under the North west rebellion last year, excluding those who have been convicted of high treason, the amnesty does not include the prisoners actually undergoing sentences, but those who have been sentenced to death or to imprisonment for a term of years.

Winnipeg, July 14. John Craig went shortly to visit the North-West.

The Canadian Pacific has decided to send a special train to the scene of the recent trouble, to bring back the bodies of the victims.

It is believed that the trouble would have been prevented.

There was considerable excitement today, as a number of persons who claimed they were at the scene, and there was considerable confusion.

The Premier is expected to make a statement to-night regarding the matter.

He is greatly pleased with the result of the election, which was particularly interesting, and the appearance of the new government is likely to be very pleasing to the voters, and he might well expect the Corporation address. Tomorrow he will go to the west, and Friday next to the Pacific Coast, where he will spend some days.

On his return, he will visit Montreal, and spend a week at Winnipeg, and go east.

The dispatches of Palmer parallel the events with great success, six thousand men in line.

There has been some change taking place in the military authorities.

In Gladstone's address to parliament it is expected that the present will resign, Gladstone will have to rely upon his colleagues on Saturday. The Premier will attend without regret, but he will have to rely upon Palmer.

They will have the privilege of a full

General Merchants

Indian Traders.

WM. STOBART & CO.
